displayed_text: Patient: Right. Family Member: Why are you taking prednisone with it? Patient: So Doctor: So the Zytiga, so the way Xtandi works is, if you think that we talked before about the, the testosterone has to get into the cell and do stuff. It has to bind in something in the cell called receptors. So the best way to think about it is a ball and glove. Xtandi kind of, if, if the ball is testosterone, Xtandi looks like an orange. And so it gets in the glove, and it blocks the ball. It can’t get in there. Uh, Zytiga works in a different way. It blocks the enzymes that the body uses to make testosterone. So there’s all these different precursors. So start with cholesterol, and it goes through about ten steps, and ends at testosterone. When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So what they found is if you give a little bit of prednisone, which is also kind of a hormone, it balances that out. Uh, so we just give a once-a-day low dose, and that seems to be enough to keep the potassium normal. But some people don’t like prednisone. It makes them feel weird. It makes them gain weight. It makes them eat more. Patient: Oh. (Laughter) Doctor: And so, uh, the standard dose was twice a day. We found that if we just give it once a day, it’s enough to counterbalance the thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so I think either one would be fine. You know? I think choosing either one would be fine. But I think that’s what I would do next is- now, the way I do that is, the other side effect of these drugs are they’re very expensive. So what we do is, uh, we have a whole group here whose job is, if we decide we’re going to do one or the other, I will call them today, and say, “I want to put you on X.”

Patient: How long does it take to see the CAT scan? Doctor: Oh, (sigh) Patient: Do I have to wait to see it? Doctor: No. I don’t think you need to. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Because, you know, everything’s going okay, and, uh- Patient: But if you see something, you’ll call me? Doctor: Yes. If anything changes, we’ll call you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, given your last time’s PSA continued to go down, I’m not too worried. Patient: Okay. Good. You know where I am, right? Doctor: Yeah, from point nine to one point one and you’re feeling good except for your neck. Patient: Yeah. I feel good.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.10 years ago or more: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::10 years ago or more

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.American Indian or Alaska Native: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::American Indian or Alaska Native

displayed_text: Patient: Okay, so you’ll know whether the castration is working or not with the hormone Family Member: After the three months of the chemo and hormone pills, how does the hormone deprivation continue? Is that – it starts now? Okay. Doctor: About every three months. Family Member: I’m sorry if you said this, but how long does the radiation go? Doctor: The radiation takes two months, coming to the hospital five days a week. I forget where you live. Patient: C___ Doctor: So you can actually go to G____. Patient: Okay, perfect. Family Member: Oh wow! Doctor: I’m sure G____has a machine. Family Member: And they do as good a job to here? Doctor: Oh yeah, same people, same machines.

Family Member: Study patient. Well, not study. Off study. Doctor: But, oh my. Oh my. Family Member: Hi, Dr. H___. Doctor: Hi. Lovely to see your father. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s amazing. Just waiting on the final stuff from administration. Everything else is okeydokey. So he’ll take his time filling out this lovely paperwork while you do damage control and try to fix our inpatient unit, please. Doctor: Shoot. Patient: I’ve got several questions for ya now. If I get the drug, what are the most common side effects? Doctor: I would say, fatigue. Patient: Fatigue? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. It’s kind of, it’s a little bit of a weird fatigue. You know? Like sometimes your brain’s okay, but your body doesn’t want to get off the couch. So you can’t really yell at him that much if that happens. But if it’s too much on the couch, then we’re going to have to, you know, reduce the number of pills. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, yeah. Patient: And if I am on the drug-

Family Member: Will he need to have somebody come with him? Doctor: Uh, no, but how is he going to – do you have transportation arrangements made? Family Member: He drives. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: He drives. Shit. J__ drives everywhere. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Is for the biopsy that we will need to do – Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - for the study and on the day that he’s just starting something new- Family Member: Yeah. Right. Doctor: I would- Family Member: You want somebody here. Doctor: At least tell you that you need to be available if we need to call you.

Patient: Yeah. It, it was two hundred and fifty dollars. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Two hundred and— Family Member: It’s okay. We got to test twenty people. We’ll take the reduced price. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Well. If, but, if there isn’t – Family Member: Oh, we’re still going to do it Patient: Don’t hesitate to Doctor: Yeah. Oh, I know, I know, I know. I know, I know. Patient: I mean --- Family Member: So Patient: I understand some people Doctor: And, you know, that’s a test also they could just do on their own. They can go to web site and order the test.

Patient: He asked about Lupron. He said Aligard. I said it’s the same thing. It’s not. Doctor: You’re right. Chemically, we do it to say this is what's happening Patient: Right. Doctor: - to your testosterone but everyone reacts to the different preparations differently. Patient: The Lupron just knocked me for a loop. They wanted me to be on Lupron for three years, and after a year, I told him I'd rather die. Doctor: Yeah, because it was terrible. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but the Aliguard’s okay right? Patient: Aliguard is okay. I'm tired. Yeah, but it doesn’t totally destabilize my life. Doctor: Right, right. I think when you get off the Xtandi, you're actually gonna feel a little bit better. Because you know, at four pills a day does weigh on you. So I think that would be better. But I'm gonna talk to S____, our research nurse who's covering for M____ who's our regular research nurse. But S___ will come in here and will just go over and see how you feel about it. You know if you're interested, great. We'll move forward and do what we need to do. We have to check to make sure all these lovely things can stay on and if not, we do regular chemo. Family Member: Well, it makes me feel good is one big concern. I get is that if he starts getting so much bone loss he can't function and his quality of life and if you can zap areas at which I didn't know. Yeah, it makes me realize hey he can have a quality of life. Doctor: Oh yeah that's number one. Family Member: There you go S___.

Family Member: Yes. Doctor: to just you may want use that one-eight hundred number. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: It’s easier. It takes away the fact of you having to follow the instructions. Family Member: All right. Doctor: And that is on my card if you really want to use that. Family Member: I have that, yeah. Doctor: Do it yourself, but otherwise, if you just tell the operator then at eight hundred to page what - Patient: Give me your Christmas present. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Okay (chuckles) Patient: No, there you go.

Family Member: You know you said Provenge is off the table but he keeps asking why. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Patient: I forgot about that, yeah. Family Member: Because the doctor said. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, no. When your PSA kind of creeps up a bit too high and you’re not as controlled and your symptomatic that’s not the group that benefits the most. There’s a kind of small amount of cancer, small amount of PSA, kind of like less than 22 would be ideal. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And then no pain. So, you’re the asymptomatic person Patient: Okay. Gotch ya. Doctor: and like uh, I got cancer, what, oh, perfect Provenge candidate. But you could get there again once like so he said can I get Provenge after Xofigo. Sure, if your pain was controlled. Even if your PSA wasn’t so low, having discomfort puts you in a different group. It just means your cancer is not behaving and having it go up on treatment is different than you not on anything and having it go up Patient: Okay. Doctor: and at this moment it’s not behaving. Patient: That’s why I’m always like at that time when I was low or no pain and that’s why he was thinking that’s what we…

Patient: -- of this is what the scan report is gonna read which I’m gonna give you right now. So this – but the same areas were the lower back and the left hip, the hip bones, so those are the two main areas. Family Member: And the rib or not the rib? Doctor: The ribs are still there and we are following it. It’s in the left side on the sixth rib. Yeah I mean that also was there before Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: and that stayed about the same. Family Member: But the increased uptake is in the lower back and the left hip? Patient: Previously we were under the impression that the scans were the good news that they haven’t changed. Doctor: I think that is still true. Okay, so my assessment of these scans are they are stable. Okay. Patient: Uh but the PSA which had been going down turned around last month to point four from one point one but then now it’s at one point four doesn’t sound good. Doctor: No. So obviously… Patient: So am I going off the Xtandi or what? Doctor: Well so we have a few choices okay. One is do we add another medication, because typically people who are sort of resistant to Xtandi. There are a couple of pathways of resistance that we know about now. Okay. One of which is something we called BET1 overexpression. B-E-T okay and you’ll get paperwork on this but. So that pathway there is a BET1 inhibitor that we are testing right now.

Patient: I’ve been fine since then. Doctor: And you’re still on the low dose right? Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Now your doctor wanted to get you off the prednisone and try Cymbalta? Patient: Well he mentioned, well he was asking me about stuff and I was telling him about the you know the blah, blah, blah. Doctor: Yeah that you’re on. Patient: And he’s said he’s had good luck with other patients that have had pain with that Cymbalta. Doctor: In the joints? I mean I don’t know how it will help with that with your pain, but you know what it’s definitely worth a try. I have no objections to giving that a try but I’m not terribly hopeful, but if he’s seen something different in his experience. Patient: Well if that’s the case I’ll just stay on the prednisone. Forget that. I mean it’s not something Doctor: Okay I mean I’m okay if you want to give that a try Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: and there’s no objection or problem - Patient: Okay.

Patient: I’m still having problems. Doctor: It takes a year generally and your surgery was when August? Patient: Uhh September. Doctor: September and so do you have any flows at all? Patient: Uh no you know it acting like it wanna but never… Doctor: And you’re taking the medicine? Patient: Uh those pills they didn’t do anything. Doctor: Okay well don’t stop taking ‘em because… Patient: Well I took ‘em. Doctor: Oh you so you finished taking them and you ran out of them is what you mean? Patient: Yeah, yeah I took ‘em. Doctor: You should have some refills. Did you look at the bottle?

Patient: If you, if you go with (game one) Doctor: Okay. Well, I’m guessing you had a- Patient: We had, we had to get up at five-thirty in the morning to go on the safari because that’s when the animals are most active. Yeah. So that was- Doctor: So what did you see? Like what animals did you see? Patient: Oh, we saw, we saw the five big ones. Doctor: Oh, really? Patient: Yeah. The elephant, giraffe, lions. Doctor: And where did you go? What like park or what was? Family Member: Kruger National Park. Patient: Kruger. Doctor: Kruger. Yeah. I’ve heard about that. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: I would say, yeah I’m not gonna do that. Doctor: You take one or two at a time. Family Member: Call Monday and say we need more. Patient: Yeah, right. Yeah, this stuff’s really good. Doctor: The next thing you know the DEA is going H____ I hear you’re off this. No, not me. And I think here we have to, let me see, how do we get this from you? So, this is just a lot of the, sort of like a list and a contract if you will. Sort of these are all the risks, this is why we’re doing it. So, every time we prescribe opiates we have to do that now. Patient: I have to sign this? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yes, I know, my family doctor, same thing. Doctor: Yeah. So, I think you have to sign signature of patient here, right here. Patient: Okay Alright. Doctor: So use that and then date it. That’s right. Family Member: If he does the chemo or radium Doctor: Yeah

Patient: No I ain’t saw you either. (Laughs) Doctor: W____ will come in with the paperwork and then we’ll get you out of here. Patient: Okay fine. Doctor: Okay? Any questions? Patient: No. Doctor: No? Patient: No not really. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Not at this point anyway. Doctor: Awesome. Happy New Year to both of you. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: Nice to see you, nice to see you.
